Call for submissions: Share your journals, share your stories

We're putting together a 1001 Journals book proposal to shop around to publishers, and need your input. To get the publishers excited, we'd like to share some remarkable journal entries, and stories that go along with them. If you'd like us to consider including your journal / entries / story in the proposal, please email us the following:

• Your Username
• The journal number
• Your city, state, and country
• A brief description of the entries, and why they're amazing (make sure they've been added to the 1001J site, where we can review them)
• If there's a story, please include it with as much detail as you can

The deadline is June 9th. 
Email submissions to someguy@1001journals.com

Don't have anything to submit? You've got time, create something unique and interesting. This is your chance to get published. Not on 1001journals.com? Sign up and start sharing journals.

Journal Contributions could range from amazing art or writing to controversial entries, humor, raw emotion, confessions, interaction between contributors, conflicts, rants, oddities, and so on.

Journal Stories might be something interesting that happened with the journal, or in your life involving the journal. Was the journal left in a library? Taken on spring break? Was it used as a marriage proposal? Perhaps you discovered it for sale in a thrift store, or shared it with reformed convicts. Let us know.

Thanks, and keep on journaling,


someguy
www.1001journals.com

It's been awhile since I created a postcard for my 76 Postcards for Dad Project.   I don't know how many I've created so far-I really should count them up.  Last night I made this one.

Here are the first pages of my Japanese moleskine.  My theme is "Colorful Women".  Of all the groups, ours is the only one doing mixed media/collage.  This was done as part of the moly_x: international sketch exchange.  It will be on its way to Germany.

Anyway, the issue comes out June 1st.

Hong Kong, Germany, Argentina, Mexico...Oh the places my moleskine can go!
  I'm bouncing up and down because I was just asked to participate in an International Moleskine exchange.
  I never do swaps or round robins any more-no time, no desire for dead lines and pressure.  Plus I've had journals go missing.  But I may make an exception for this.

This is for an LJ artist friend who can do anything.  I'm not saying who it is, she'll just have to be surprised.  

Gaudy  hand drawn and colored atc.on shiny paper

I have a wonderful art friend who I've been exchanging artwork with for awhile now. She does the most wonderful drawings and watercolors. Getting a postcard from her is always a nice treat, especially since it's her hand drawn work.
I do love collage, yes. But there is something really special about a piece of artwork that has been drawn and colored entirely by hand. Is there anything more daring or personal? From one's brain and imagination, telegraphed by one's hand to paper?
So she sends me her art and I always reply, sometimes later than I'd like, but I always do, with a hand drawn, colored creation of my own. It never fails to make me to slow down, draw, color, paint-get lost in what I'm doing. I always feel calm afterwards. 
For my friend,
silverfishes  
 

"Angel of the Desert" 4x6 

I finished a cloth bead and a beaded quiltie, several postcards too, but haven't had time to take pictures of them...

This is my first attempt at this  4X4 inches., untitled so far.
My mom and I talked about Dad while I embroidered, told stories and swapped memories.  I really enjoyed doing this project.  I think I will put it in a shadow box.
